und.safe_value: Shades of red indicate where monthly average temperatures were up to 11° Fahrenheit warmer than the 1981–2010 average. Shades of blue show where monthly average temperatures were up to 11° Fahrenheit cooler than the long-term average. The darker the color, the larger the difference from average—white and very light areas were close to the long-term average temperature.
und.value: Shades of red indicate where monthly average temperatures were up to 11° Fahrenheit warmer than the 1981–2010 average. Shades of blue show where monthly average temperatures were up to 11° Fahrenheit cooler than the long-term average. und.safe_value: Data Access URL above should perhaps be an FTP site and this field will list the shapefiles used...
und.value: Data Access URL above should perhaps be an FTP site and this field will list the shapefiles used...

und.safe_value: Monitoring how temperatures around the globe compare to their long-term average each month gives climate scientists a way to check Earth's overall temperature trend. Though some areas are cooler than usual and other areas are warmer than usual, changes in the overall average show a decades-long trend of increasing temperatures.
und.value: Monitoring how temperatures around the globe compare to their long-term average each month gives climate scientists a way to check Earth's overall temperature trend. Though some areas are cooler than usual and other areas are warmer than usual, changes in the overall average show a decades-long trend of increasing temperatures.

und.title: Climate Monitoring Branch, National Climatic Data Center

und.safe_value: Temperature readings come from weather stations in the Global Historical Climate Network. Difference from Average values are calculated by averaging daily temperatures observed at individual stations, and subtracting them from the long-term average temperature for each location. To produce the final map, visualization specialists use a mathematical process to smooth transitions and fill blank spaces.
und.value: Temperature readings come from weather stations in the Global Historical Climate Network. Difference from Average values are calculated by averaging daily temperatures observed at individual stations, and subtracting them from the long-term average temperature for each location. To produce the final map, visualization specialists use a mathematical process to smooth transitions and fill blank spaces.

und.safe_value: Colors show where temperatures were warmer or cooler than the long-term average for this month. The darker the color, the larger the difference from the average temperature..

Where did these measurements come from?

und.safe_value: Original GHCN data are smoothed using a nearest-neighbor algorithm developed by NOAA's Environmental Visualization Laboratory. Unsmoothed versions of these data are available at http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/sotc/service/global/map-blended-mntp/YYYYMM.gif
